author: Special Correspondent
text:
The 14th Tamil Nadu Assembly came to an abrupt end with Speaker P. Dhanapal rushing through his speech and even asking it to be considered it as read to adjourn it sine die exactly at 3 p.m.

Finance Minister O. Panneerselvam, keeping an eye on the clock, gave his elaborate reply to the discussion on the interim budget.

The House then passed the bills one by one+

. The Speaker was magnanimous in allowing the CPI (M) and CPI MLAs to raise questions on the Tamil Nadu Value Added Tax (Amendment) Bill, 2016 and the Tamil Nadu Marine Fishing Regulation (Amendment) Bill, 2016.

The Left MLAs argued that the regulations proposed in the Bill could jeopardise the livelihood of fishermen who were already suffering. CPI (M) MLA K. Balakrishnan urged the government to refer it to the select committee.

When the Fisheries Minister K.A. Jayapal tried to reply, he was asked to move the bill fast and it was passed in a hurry.

As the clock ticked to 3 p.m, the Speaker chose to wind up his speech fast and asked the members to consider it as read to adjourn the proceedings sine die.

In his speech, he had mentioned that the 14{+t}{+h}Assembly had met for 197 days in the past five years over 11 sessions, lasting 918 hours. The Chief Minister had addressed the House for 7.28 hours. As many as 28 members had attended the House on all days in the past five years. Over 1.15 lakh visitors were allowed to watch the proceedings.

In their speech, both Finance Minister O. Panneerselvam and Speaker P. Dhanapal expressed confidence that Ms. Jayalalithaa would return to power by emerging victorious in the 2016 Assembly elections.

Speaker Dhanapal rushes through speech, asks members to consider it as read
title: Session comes to an abrupt end
